boardgame.description:
The handbook of organising LARPs.

Translated from back of the book:
Handbook of organizing LARPs (Larpinjärjestäjän käsikirja) is a guide for makers of LARP. The articles of this book offer advice and guidelines from writing a game to taking care of the practical issues of a game event. The book suits a beginning game organizer as a guide as well as for a more experienced organizer for finding new ideas and ways of action. From its pages you will find both common advice about making LARP events and also more precise observations about characteristics of for example an urban environment as game area, about science fiction striving for realism as game style or about how big size of the game affects the organizing.

"Life is a life-long journey of learning and so is organizing LARPs. This is an important reading package for all of us, who wish to make better games!" -Mike Pohjola

In Finnish:
Larpinjärjestäjän käsikirja on opas live-roolipelin tekijälle. Kirjan artikkelit tarjoavat neuvoja ja ohjeita niin pelin kirjoittamisesta kuin pelitapahtuman käytännön järjestämisestäkin. Kirja sopii niin aloittelevalle pelinjärjestäjälle oppaaksi kuin kokeneemmalle tekijälle uusien ideoiden ja toteuttamistapojen löytämiseen. Sen sivuilta löydät sekä yleisluontoisia neuvoja live-roolipelin tekemisestä että tarkempia huomioita erityispiirteistä joita vaikkapa kaupunkiympäristö pelipaikkana, realismiin pyrkivä science fiction pelin tyylinä tai pelin suuri koko tuovat järjestämistyöhön.

boardgame.name: They're Coming
boardgame.description:
They're Coming is a zombie survival game. You must move your survivors through several locations to the rescue station while fighting off your opponent's zombies.

Depending on the version of the game, players have two modes of play. In the "Single Pack" or "Travel Edition" of the game, one player take on the role of the survivors and the other the zombies; in the "Standard" or "Two Pack" version, both players take turns being survivors and zombies in a round of play. Survivors draw from a survivor supply deck and must navigate locations (chosen by the opponent) that are infested with zombies (which are played from the opponent's zombie deck).

In the Standard game, the player who gets the most uninfected survivors to the rescue station wins. Non-standard games can be played by increasing the number of locations that survivors must pass through and/or by reducing the number of survivors to start the game.

boardgame.name: Giant's Rapture (C&C)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Adventure Type: Overland, Dungeon
Level: 5-8 listed on back (6 - 8 Listed on title page)
Party: 4 to 8 characters (listed on title page)
Setting: Portable to Home-brew

Eurich Gunshoff IV, Count of Kleaves, is beset by powerful enemies. The King to the north has laid waste his holdings beyond the Tot River and even now threatens the river castles. Only the coming winter holds him at bay, giving the Count time, if only a little, to muster his strength.

Long have the people of Kleaves worshiped the gods of the south, and it is to these people that he turns, striking a bargain with the powerful King of Kaymor. In exchange for a precious gift the Kayomarese promise to aid Eurich and his people, but it is Eurich's charge to deliver the prize. He can spare few troops, and with spies all about he cannot be too careful.

The prize he sets in a wagon in a caravan, and as escort he calls upon those who dwell upon the fringes of society, adventurers who seek fame, gold and glory. They are charged to cross the wilderness and deliver the wagons safely. But the road is fraught with danger.

Walls of stone block the road and winter upon the open plains carries dangers beyond the biting cold. But more than stone and frost, the end promises fire without comfort. Designed in 3 parts, Giant's Rapture offers overland travel, dungeon, and intrigue and pits the character's wits against the open road and one another.

Designed as a Tourney Adventure Giant's Rapture contains three adventures: A Stone's Wager, Winter's Promise, and Trial by Fire.

boardgame.name: Let's Play Two! Baseball Game
boardgame.description:
Let's Play Two! Baseball Game is a free, print and play baseball game released by Hot Stove Games in 2002. The game is designed to replicate what Henry Waugh's Universal Baseball Association Game may have looked like from the book, "The Universal Baseball Association Inc. J. Henry Waugh Prop." by Robert Coover. This allows you to create your own baseball league where players grow old, become all-stars or simply fade away from the league. From rookie to retirement you follow their careers and act as commissioner and God of their universe just as Henry Waugh did in the book.

The game is played by rolling three six sided dice to simulate a baseball game. Batters can hit for power, strike out, walk, etc. based on their roll. The unique thing about this game is if you play a full season the rules have you "re-rate" players based on their seasonal performance to continue play to the next season. This way, you create a living, breathing baseball universe with your own champions, hall of famers, and heros!

boardgame.name: Yggdrasil (Second Edition with Asgard Expansion)
boardgame.description:
Yggdrasil, the “terrible steed”, a cosmic ash tree that supports the nine worlds, is in jeopardy. As the Ragnarök approaches, you, mighty among the Æsir and Vanir Gods, have to face the relentless advance of Evil Forces. You must sacrifice everything to prevent Evil from destroying Yggdrasil. The last battle, predicted since the dawn of time, is starting now. Your only aim is to repel the Evil Forces in order for Yggdrasil to survive this universe at war.

Yggdrasil is a co-operative game for 1-6 players. Playing the role of a Norse god, you must, with the other players, stop the advancing Evil Forces in Asgard.

This NEW EDITION includes the Asgard expansion.

Asgard contains twelve double-sided god tiles, with a god's usual power on one side and the Trance power on the other.

-Description from Z-Man Games web site

boardgame.name: Der Eiserne Thron: Das Kartenspiel – Geheime Pläne
A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – A Hidden Agenda
Juego de Tronos: El Juego de Cartas – Un Plan Inescrutable
Le Trône de Fer: Le Jeu de Cartes – Un Dessein Caché
boardgame.description:
Marywn smiled a ghastly smile, the juice of the sourleaf running red between his teeth. “Who do you think killed all the dragons the last time around? Gallant dragonslayers armed with swords?”
–George R.R. Martin, A Feast for Crows

A Hidden Agenda is the sixth and final Chapter Pack in the Kingsroad cycle for A Game of Thrones: The Card Game. Schemes, secrets, and mysteries pervade its sixty new cards (three copies each of twenty individual cards), drawing the Kingsroad cycle to its climactic conclusion. As it grants players new means to make their final bids for the Iron Throne in a Westeros forever scarred by the War of the Five Kings, A Hidden Agenda asks the question, “Who is truly pulling the strings?”

Are the Lords of the Great Houses the powers to watch? Should the Lords be less concerned with each other and more concerned with Daenerys Targaryen and her three growing dragons? Or are the kingdoms’ advisors the ones who are secretly pulling the strings? All the previous Chapter Packs in the Kingsroad cycle have introduced new cards and tactics to blend into formerly established mechanics. Appropriately, A Hidden Agenda concludes with a wide sampling of these mechanics: the Bannerman trait, Shadows, cards at your command, decks without agendas, and the Maester trait. Each offers a different path to power, but only one House can sit the Iron Throne!

boardgame.name: Fate Worlds, Volume One: Worlds on Fire
I Mondi di Fate, volume uno: Mondi in Fiamme
boardgame.description:
From the back of the book:

Flexible RPG systems like Fate Core are terrific if you have the time and energy to put into building a world. But we also realize that sometimes extensive prep just isn't feasible. The good news? You can still experience the Fate awesomeness with the help of the Fate Worlds expansion.

Fate Worlds Volume 1: Worlds on Fire is the first in a two-volume set. In Worlds on Fire, you get six rich story settings. Each setting includes custom mechanics, NPCs, and story elements—all ready to go using the system provided in Fate Core. We've got you covered regardless of your flavor of RPG choice. Divest an evil cult of a powerful idol in Tower of the Serpents, or experience the small town supernatural in White Picket Witches. Explore the lives, loves, and losses of fire fighters in Fight Fire, or take on a horde
of WWI mechanical monstrosities in Kriegszeppelin Valkyrie.

Whether you stick with one world or go on grand tour, Fate Worlds will provide everything you need to develop your Fate Core adventure except the snacks.

Fate worlds. All the worlds. Your stage.

boardgame.name: Slovenský a český film
boardgame.description:
Slovenský a český film (Slovak and Czech Cinema) is a movie trivia game.
In the game, there are 1800 interesting questions mainly about Slovak cinema and also 300 tasks for the party variant of the game. Questions are divided into six areas: film before 1989, after 1989 , filmmakers and actors, bedtime stories and fairy tales, movie lines and misc. You move your piece by throwing a dice and you have to answer one question in every category correctly before going to answer three final questions. First player to do this wins a game.
There is also a party game variant where you perform, describe or draw movies or filmmakers.

Components:
Double-sided game board
One Die
300 cards with 1800 trivia questions
100 cards with 300 party version tasks
6 Player Tokens (1 x 6 Colors)
36 Scoring Wedges (6 x 6 Colors)
One sand timer for party version
Rules of Play

boardgame.name: Linkee
Linkee!
boardgame.description:
Linkee is a trivia party game that can be played by individual players or teams.

Questions on a card are read out but answers are kept secret. Once all questions and a further clue have been given players must work out what links those answers and shout Linkee! Get it right and win the card. Each question card has a letter on the back. Once you have the correct letters to spell Linkee you win the game.

Described as a shouty outy family game, the game is intended to be boisterous family fun.

boardgame.name: Dame Una Pista
Ruck Zuck
boardgame.description:
Based on the popular long running 1988-2000 and 2004-2005 Tele 5, RTL II, tm3 and currently RTLplus since 2016 German game show of the same name. (for which in turn was originally adapted from a short-lived 1986 U.S. daytime game show on ABC called Bruce Forsyth's Hot Streak) First, the players determine which set of cards to work with. Then it determines the starting player, for which they continue clockwise. The first player pulls on the clock and draws the top card from the deck. Then He/She submits to his/her right players and starts the clock. the player must then now decide on which of the two generic terms the he/she will use and announce them. He/She then list three terms matching the topic while stopping the clock. The hands of the clock displays the score, which is listed in the circular column under the name of the player. Then the timer switches to the next player. In the following four rounds, five and even six terms must be found in the same subject.

The bonus round is also somewhat different that the actual TV series. for which the active player can draw new cards for so long, until the clock expires. For each card completely played, the player gets a point. Cards can continued to be pulled out until the time expires. at the end of the round, the Player will receive one point for each completed card that has been played. The winner is the player whose total is after the bonus round is the winner.

boardgame.name: Krakens
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This particular installment of Exotic Encounters focuses on the kraken. These oceanic titans are staples of oceanic fantasy (and science fiction), and it seems a wonder that any ship can cross the ocean without being downed by one of these great squids. In the transition from 3.5 OGL to Pathfinder, the mighty kraken got much mightier, skyrocketing its CR up into a realm where few players are likely to reach. As a result, all of the krakens in this book attempt to create meaningful encounters with evil squids that can be fairly attempted by characters who aren’t nearly at their peak already. The first of these is the barbed kraken (CR 8), a smaller kraken that lacks the size, shipwrecking capacity, and magical talent of the standard kraken, but which has poisonous and debilitating barbs on its long arms, and a maddening glare fitting for a monster of the deep. The seaquake kraken (CR 13) specializes in creating giant vortices in the water, which it uses to sink ships and devour their crews. Finally, the dominator kraken (CR 15) is even more intelligent than its kin, and can project a telepathic field that allows it to control each and every creature within range.

boardgame.name: Piles
boardgame.description:
Piles is played using a standard 52 card deck, by four players in teams of two. Team members are opposite each other. The dealer deals out 10 cards for each player, one by one; the remaining 12 cards are placed in the middle of the desk, arranged in a 4x3 rectangle called “Castle”. The player left to the dealer starts play placing one card on the Castle; the others will follow in clockwise order. The color (red or black) of the first card played by the opener assigns the color of each team for that game: e.g., if the opener chooses to play a 3 of Hearts, he and his partner will be the Reds, and the other team the Blacks. Goal of the Reds is to score points by capturing black cards, and vice versa for the Blacks. Cards are to be placed on the Castle, on top of those already on the desk, forming piles controlled by the card on top of it. Each card has an intrinsic value that follows the natural order, starting from the Ace (1) up to the King (13). In the Castle, each card can have from 2 up to 4 neighbors, i.e. cards adjacent either horizontally or vertically. The total value of a card on the Castle is equal to its intrinsic value increased by 1 for each neighbor of the same color and decreased by 1 for each of the opposite: e.g. a red 10 having 3 red and 1 black neighbors, will have a total value equal to the intrinsic value of a Queen.

Rules of the game:
1 - it's alway allowed to place on top of a card another card of the same color
2- a card of the opposite color can be placed, changing the control of the pile, if the card to be placed has an intrinsic value higher than the total value of the card on top of that pile
3- a player can pass the turn. In that case, the opponent at his left will pick at random one of his cards. That card will be added to the piles picked up at the end of the game, possibly contributing to the score.

End of the game and scoring:
A game is over after 10 turns, when the players run out of cards. Each team picks up the piles topped by the cards of their color: all the cards of the opposite color inside the controlled piles are captured and used for the final score. In the final scoring, an Ace is worth 9 points, a King 4, a Queen 3, a Jack 2 and the remaing cards 1 point each. The Red team will sum up the values of the captured black cards, and the other way around for the Blacks.

Two players game:
The game can also be played by two players, under the same rules. In that case, when the two players run out of the first 10 cards, the dealer will deal out the remaing and the game will go on as usual.

boardgame.name: Zombie Solitaire
boardgame.description:
Zombie Solitaire is like regular Klondike solitaire with one big difference: you get to save survivors and destroy Zombies!!!

Components:
Zombie Solitaire requires [2] decks of regular playing cards (including one “joker”), One deck will be used for the [52] cards and [1] joker. The other deck will supply the [7] zombies "the logo side of the cards" and four sets of A thru 6 for the [4] ammo boxes with 6 shots each.

You could use 4d6 instead of the four sets of A thru 6 for the ammo.

COMPONENTS:
Two normal decks of cards
• [1] 52 card deck for basic game play.
• [1] Joker, which represents you!
• [1] second 52 CARD deck, from which 31 cards are needed. These cards represent zombies that must be destroyed and ammo for your gun.
• [4] six-sided dice, representing a supply of ammunition for your gun

Zombie Solitaire can also be played using a specialized PnP version “Zombie deck”.
PnP cards
• [4] Ace: a Safe House
• [4] King: Grandpa – the only character willing to sacrifice himself for his family
• [4] Queen: Grandma
• [4] Jack: Dad
• [4] 10: Mom
• [4] 9: the children and their friends
• [4] 8: the children and their friends
• [4] 7: the children and their friends
• [4] 6: the children and their friends
• [4] 5: the children and their friends
• [4] 4: the children and their friends
• [4] 3: the children and their friends
• [4] 2: the children and their friends
• [1] Joker: You, the armed and dangerous hero
• [7] Zombies - Cards from the second deck (logo side only)
• 4D6 die: ammo box (6 rounds each)

Setup:
Zombie Solitaire is set up like regular “Klondike” solitaire with 7 stacks, four collection zones for aces, and a draw pile – all from a single deck of cards. In addition, 10 cards from a second deck are set, faced down, in a pile to the right of the 7 stacks. The joker is placed below the zombie pile, with the [4] dice off to the side.
• Draw pile: crowd of survivors from the zombie apocalypse
• 7 stacks: temporary shelters to which some of the survivors have fled and others may follow. Cards that are face-down are temporarily hidden from view; when they are turned over, they can be spotted by the zombies
• 10-card pile (from second deck): zombie horde
• Collection zones: areas in which safe houses may be established

Game Play:
The game is played like regular Klondike solitaire, with the usual options – moving cards from stack to stack, turning cards over when they become open, pulling the aces out and setting cards on top of them as appropriate – until the first card is drawn from the deck. That’s when the zombies finally arrive – and all bets are off!

In Zombie Solitaire, only one survivor card – the top card of the deck – is drawn each time.
Play the game as normal, but with the following adjustments:
• You do not have to play a survivor card that you have drawn from the draw pile even if you have an available play. It is always your choice whether or not to play a card.
• You cannot play a survivor card on top of a zombie card.
• You cannot move any card (or stack) that is under attack from a zombie and you cannot move any card (or stack) onto a stack that is under attack from a zombie – until the zombie is destroyed
• You do not come under attack for drawing an ace from the survivor draw pile (or from one of the stacks) and setting it up as a safe house and you do not come under attack for moving a survivor to a safe house.
• You can move a king (and its stack) to an empty space on the board without coming under attack as long as there is no zombie on the king's stack. But if you move a king from the draw pile to the board, it will come under attack .
You do not come under attack when a survivor moves from stack to stack.
When you draw the last card from the draw deck and flip the deck over, this causes a zombie to attack the oldest survivor at the bottom of a stack.

When a second zombie attacks a stack the lowest card on the stack is eaten but that survivor destroys both of the zombies.

Zombie threat:
Individual zombies are not a threat to the survivors. They are endangered only when two zombies attack at the same time. When a second zombie card is added to a temporary shelter stack, the bottom survivor card is removed from the game (where it will contribute no victory points to the player’s total). The attack will also destroy one of the zombies, whose card is returned to the zombie horde.

Victory:
The game is over when you no longer have any available moves, no kings to sacrifice and no ammunition. Count up the number of Safe Houses you established and the number of survivors who made it to a Safe House. You get [1] victory point for each.
A perfect score is 52.
